The individual has little or no ability to ensure the privacy of his or her affairs. The common law has not been able to give continued guarantees of individual rights.

Honourable senators will find that this is so. At one stage, of course, the common law promoted slavery and had to be changed by legislation in Britain and in the United States of America. So the common law does not have a very clean record. It has provided some useful provisions that are akin to Bill of Rights legislation, but in other instances it has not moved much at all. It is very sporadic. Thirdly, the Human Rights Commission has been dealt with. It is an existing body which many feel could provide the proper remedy with some updating and upgrading. Maybe we do not need a Bill of Rights; a Human Rights Commission with representatives from the States on it may be sufficient, without the litigiousness involved in a Bill of Rights. It is a matter for discussion by this Parliament as to whether or not it can do this adequately.

Fourthly, the parliaments, which people often think are protectors of human rights, protect some human rights but also ride roughshod over others, as those of us who have been concerned with privilege in this Parliament have noticed recently. In fact the Parliament deals only in a very indirect way with the question of human rights and does not constantly monitor it.

It is very useful to examine in this report the way in which existing remedies and institutions may or may not cover the situation. A model Bill of Rights is set out in the report which suggests that that investigation of State branches is necessary.

I think that members of the Committee are rather strongly of the view, although we do not make a recommendation, that a Bill of Rights implying international covenants must be applicable to the whole of Australia and must have some reference not only to Commonwealth laws but also to the vast number of other laws, particularly State laws, which perhaps impinge more directly on human beings, which are more likely to lead to interference with human rights and which we know in some cases have done so. How we do that without provoking some tremendous fights with the States, I think, is a matter for serious consideration by this Parliament.

I have grave doubts about the idea of a State `displacing' the law, which is the model put forward in the Committee's report. It is an idea, but it is also doubtful whether it will constitutionally meet the mark. We may take an international convenant and apply it under the external affairs powers, but that need not be done entirely. If we change the language or try to implement something different, or if we try to implement other conditions-and people very often have suggested in submissions to this Committee, for example, that this should be done in relation to the rights of the States to take property without any just terms, which, as we know, does not apply to the Commonwealth-we have to find some other constitutional means of endorsing that and entitling it to be done. Therefore, some risks are involved in any provision which enables States to walk--

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't want to take a risk, would you?

—You may take a risk. After we have had blood on the floor and Premiers screaming blue murder and saying that the Bill of Rights will do certain things, I think the currently suggested Bill of Rights is a rather meek and poor model. Other people think it is very strong. If we had an enormous fight over this and found that it was knocked out by the High Court of Australia, we would wonder whether `it was worth the candle'. I do not say that a Bill of Rights is not necessary. If we do not have a proper and effective Human Rights Commission, or something like that, I think we may have to have a Bill of Rights to set out the rules.
—An effective Human Rights Commission.
—The Human Rights Commission may be the instrument if given additional powers. I am not saying that it necessarily is.
—What sorts of powers?

—Unfortunately, the honourable senator interrupts so quietly that I cannot hear him properly. Whether that is the remedy of whether we need to have a formal statement which sets out the rights and which may be of very good educational benefit for the people of Australia as it would draw our attention to these things--
—You wouldn't want to enforce it, though.
—We may have to enforce it. If there were no other method, I would take it as second best; but I hope that we will not need to do that.
—We are not here for that, are we?

—We will have to see as the debate unfolds. This Committee of the Senate has rehearsed the arguments and given us all a chance to put aside some of the prejudices which are held in this community. One sees extraordinary things in the Press from day to day. It is claimed that the Bill of Rights will do so and so and something else. Very often I say: `I wish it would, but I am sure it would not'. On the contrary, we must put aside some of the illusions and prejudices in respect of this matter and look at it as rational and sensible Australian legislators. The Committee has done something which will be valuable from this point of view. One will not find any recommendations anywhere in the Committee's report, but I think that one will find good arguments which help in the general debate that will take place on this subject over the next few years. Therefore, I very much commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. In doing so I wish initially to congratulate all of those who were involved in working with the Committee, especially the Secretariat-Dr Gary Rumble and his staff-for the amount of work which they put into the Committee's inquiry. It was a very important inquiry because, as we now know, the Government has come up with a proposed Bill of Rights which is under consideration by the Parliament. As we also know, the inquiry was embarked upon before the Government decided upon the proposal of a Bill of Rights. In speaking, obviously, as one of the unanimous endorsers of the report, I wish to say a couple of things about the report and some aspects of it which I think are of importance.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole idea of a Bill of Rights arose in the Australian parliamentary context early in the days of the Whitlam Government. I think it is important to note, in the context of the debate which is taking place at the moment, that this is one other item of the agenda set by the Whitlam Government between 1972 and 1975. It is one of those items which were proposed by the then Attorney-General, Senator Lionel Murphy, and one of those which are still being developed 10 years later, like many other proposals of that time. It took quite some time-in fact, five years; 13 November 1980-for Australia to ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. In doing so, we have an obligation in international law not only to respect the covenant but also to ensure that all persons within this country have the rights set down in the covenant. It meant that people in this country would have rights without distinction such as to race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status; the rights would be equal. Since that day we have committed ourselves to adopting some sort of enforcement procedures necessary to give effect to the rights recognised in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The first point I want to make regarding the Bill is that even though the report recommends that, in the first instance, we do not change the Constitution to entrench a Bill of Rights and that, in fact, what we should do is legislate to have operating within our country a Bill of Rights situation, I think that this legislation should continue for a trial period. If one were to read the report one would find that this question is left open. I would like to see a period of five years or so in order to test the legislation in this country. It is the sort of operation which took place in Canada. It is one that I think is important in Australia so that we can, at the end of the five or six-year period, move towards entrenching within our Constitution a Bill of Rights which will overcome all law, both State and Federal. As I have said, this is a long term goal and it needs to take place after a period of ordinary legislation, after a period during which people will understand not only what their rights are but also the obligations they have to other people within the community.

The second point about which my feelings are extremely strong-it was left for debate in this Senate and discussion within the Parliament-is to what extent a Bill of Rights should operate on the States. I do not think that we can have an effective mechanism to protect rights in this country unless that mechanism binds all Australians and all Australian governments. It need apply not only to the Commonwealth but also to the States and the Northern Territory. Today we have seen an instance of why that should happen. The Queensland Government's intention of once again gerrymandering the law in that country is a stark example of what this sort of Bill of Rights provision could combat. When we look at the inquiry that the Senate Committee has conducted we find that many of the laws that have been inconsistent with the rights in the ICCPR are State laws. Most of the laws that infringe upon freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and the criminal process rights are State laws. Questions dealing with cruel or inhumane treatment of prisoners, punishment of them, or improper segregation of prisoners and hospital patients are State laws. On the whole, submissions put to the Committee suggested that if we were to look at an effective Bill of Rights the States should not be exempt from it.

State laws are more likely to be barriers to ethnic, religious, or lingusitic minorities enjoying their group rights under the covenants. If a Bill of Rights does not apply to the States or the Northern Territory, and I believe this after this inquiry has been conducted-once again we have had a stark example of what the Northern Territory economic cowboys can do-it will fail to reach out into the areas of most need in the Australian community.

Why do we need a Bill of Rights? There are quite a number of reasons. I have mentioned the fact that rights in this community are most affected by State legislatures. Essentially there are four reasons why a national Bill of Rights should apply across the board. Firstly, there is an assumption in our community that under the common law rights are protected. My contention is that under the common law this assumption has been proven baseless. The common law has failed to develop and enforce a comprehensive range of civil and political rights and it has failed to protect individuals from discrimination on many grounds. It is possible-I accept this-to say that the common law has given some support to some rights but usually this has been very difficult to enforce. Under the common law we have a situation where delving through a mass of precedents we have as rights what is left after the exceptions and limitations have all been dealt with. Let us look, as one example, at the right of freedom of speech at common law. What that stands for is the freedom which is left after the censorship laws, defamation laws, contempt of court laws, contempt of parliament laws, sedition, criminal libel, blasphemy, radio and television program standards and many other limitations have been imposed.

Recent court cases have supported the view that judges have failed to develop a common law and common law rights. For example, the assumed right to assistance of counsel for persons on trial was found not to be guaranteed. Even in the most recent South Australian case of the Grace Bible Church v. Reedman, it was found that the common law has never guaranteed an inalienable right to freedom of religious worship. When one looks at the common law one finds that under the law and the application of precedents civil liberties are not protected. What we need to do is set up a charter under which the judiciary should operate.

The second compelling argument for a national Bill of Rights can be found in the fact that governments of Australia have the power to legislate on civil rights. Supposedly, rights of individuals are protected by the political pressure applied to parliamentarians in the democratic system which, it is contended, stops them from legislating away rights. One only has to look at what happened in the Queensland Parliament in recent days and what in fact happened in the New South Wales Parliament two or three years ago to see that this does not stand up. This year the Queensland Parliament has ignored pressures from all sorts of interests concerned with the protection of civil liberties and has enacted legislation which has detracted most immensely from civil liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—Senator Boswell has awoken from his Queensland stupor and asks which one. I am referring to the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985. If the honourable senator could bother to read and understand it he would see that it was so broadly drawn that the restrictions on freedom of speech and assembly have the potential to apply not only to the electricity industry workers but to workers throughout Queensland. Senator Boswell in fact epitomises the short term political gain that motivates politicians in that State. There is no concern for civil liberties and no concern for the rights of the individual. Even though he sits on the other side of the chamber, ignorantly he asks which one. He participates in a party with absolutely no respect for civil liberties in this country. We have an example in Queensland of a government implementing legislation which involves gross infringement of civil liberties. Senator Boswell, in his stupor and ignorance, sits in his place and asks which one.
—I take a point of order.
—I am being totally kind to him, Senator Lewis.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I observe that you noticed what was said. I would have thought that you would have called the honourable senator to order. It was a disgraceful remark by the fellow over there-Roy Rene over there. Is the honourable senator going to withdraw it or not?
—Senator Bolkus, I believe that you have transgressed Standing Orders by using that remark.

—I withdraw. I contend that a Bill of Rights could go a fair part of the way towards remedying these sorts of defects. Obviously it would not save us from the Senator Boswells of this Senate. However, it would save us from the sort of legislation that we now have in Queensland. So we do have that other compelling argument for a Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The educative value of a Bill of Rights is also important in alerting people not only of their rights, as I said earlier, but also of the rights of others-the rights that can be balanced in a democracy such as ours. But most importantly, a Bill of Rights could limit the power of parliament to enact laws inconsistent with it and could, of course, set the parameters for the judiciary to operate within principles set down internationally for adherence and for the recognition of rights in countries throughout the world.

The fourth critical point which I believe could be addressed by a Bill of Rights which has an all-encompassing application is that we in Australia have undertaken obligations internationally. We have undertaken obligations to ensure that everyone in Australia has the rights set down in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. We in this country have established a Human Rights Commission and, though Senator Lewis may not agree with the retention and implementation of it, the reality is that we have one. But the problem with that Commission is that it does not have power to grant redress.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was established by our Government, so what are you talking about?

—It may have been a step brought forward by the honourable senator's Government but many of his colleagues disagree with much of what his Government did and much of what his former Prime Minister now stands for. The Human Rights Commission basically operates without the power to grant redress to individuals whose rights under the covenant have been infringed not only by the States but also by agents of the Commonwealth. What is important and what is recommended by the Senate Committee report is the establishment of a system of judicial enforcement, which I believe is important if we are to pay adequate recognition to our international obligations. In essence, we are saying that we as a country have not gone far enough in addressing our obligations internationally. A Bill of Rights based on the ICCPR and on the recommendations of this Committee would go a fair way towards fulfilling those sorts of obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: The fifth important reason why I believe we need a Bill of Rights to apply throughout the States and the Commonwealth is that at the moment we have a major disparity within this country from State to State. One has only to look at the anti-discrimination provisions to see that. We in the Federal Parliament in 1984 enacted sex discrimination legislation. It operates federally.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no displacement provision there.

—I will talk about the displacement provision later, if Senator Missen would like that. New South Wales, since 1977, has had anti-discrimination legislation. South Australia had it as well, and the Victorian Government had it as well by way of its Equal Opportunity Act. Unfortunately, the advances stopped there. Western Australia has passed an Equal Opportunity Act, but it has major shortcomings. But at the same time as that, Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory do not have and do not even plan to have anti-discrimination legislation.
—Shame!

—When it comes to sexual discrimination legislation, as Senator Ryan says, it is a great shame that these States have proven themselves to be positively medieval. Senator Missen raises the question of displacement. I think that it is an important question. As I have said in the last 15 minutes, I believe that to be effective any legislation must have some sort of application on the States. It is not adequate enough for us to say, as Senator Missen might say in a very general way, `yes, well, let's beef up the Human Rights Commission', without saying how we need to beef it up. The only effective way that we can beef it up is to give it powers to apply rights throughout the country and to enforce those rights, whether it is the Human Rights Commission, another mechanism of government, or both. But there needs to be that sort of enforceability. The only way that we can get that, without the major political brawl about which Senator Missen is concerned, is to propose the system that has been operating in Canada. Let us recommend legislation of a Bill of Rights in this country which will have total application, across-the-board with the Commonwealth and across-the-board with the States, after a certain period, as we recommend, after a sunrise provision which will enable all State and Federal laws to apply for three years, up until the time when they will have to conform with the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen would contend that the battle with the States is too great to take on, to make them apply and be obliged to follow civil and human rights legislation. What we are proposing for this committee, if there is to be a Bill of Rights, is a situation in which the international covenant would apply, when Federal legislation would apply unless and until the States, by legislation, could be seen to be standing up and saying to their electorates: `We do not think that you should have the rights that the rest of Australia should have'. That puts them to the test. It puts to the test not only Liberal governments and National Party governments but also Labor governments. That is the most effective way that we can proceed at this stage. We do not bind the States. We give them the right to opt out. But if they want to opt out, they must stand up for that and stand up in their own States and communities.

I believe that this report, as Senator Tate and Senator Missen have said, will be a valuable contribution to the continuing debate about what sort of Bill of Rights we should have in this country and how it should apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —If at all.

—Senator Missen says `if at all', and that is his prerogative. However, in closing, I believe that we should have a Bill of Rights. I have some reservations and I see some shortcomings in the Bill of Rights that has been proposed by the Government, and one which is not the subject of this debate. However, what I see is that this inquiry and this report give this Senate and this Parliament a number of avenues that we can pursue in order to beef up the Bill of Rights which is floating around this Parliament. If some of the ideas were to be followed, rights in this country would be much enhanced and much more protected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few remarks to the report on a Bill of Rights for Australia by the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It is a good report and the senators who prepared it deserve some proper congratulations. I am one of them.
—Especially the Chairman.

—Yes, especially the Chairman. In addition to the senators, thanks are due to Dr Gary Rumble, the Secretary, and the research officers, Steve Curran and Sarah O'Brien, who are presently in this chamber. They worked very hard. Whether or not one considers that a Bill of Rights ought to be brought into operation, the concepts that underlie this report are fundamental to the culture in which we live, to the civilisation which we enjoy and to the concepts by which we live. I look forward to the debates about those issues when the Bill of Rights that the Government is putting forward comes into this chamber.
—Are you really looking forward to the debate, Senator?
—I look forward particularly to debate from Senator Puplick, which will be put forward with the usual aplomb and style of which he is capable.
—And brevity.

—Yes, and brevity. We might even get a comment from somebody such as Senator Parer, who usually sits there taking a quite cynical view about matters like this. Being a miner in the past, he is more interested in the economics of this nation. I want to say just a few things. There has been much discussion in the community about the concepts of common law, as if common law were some doctrine that overcomes all the problems we face. As an illustration that that is not so, I refer to the terrible trio of doctrines developed by the common law in the nineteenth century-common employment, contributory negligence and volenti. That has denied to many a person the compensation that would otherwise rightfully be due to him. One must understand the great lack that common law has and the oppression at times that is allowed to continue in the community. It was the legislation passed in reference to that which cured it.

SPEECH.PARA: Common law is not a doctrine or an institution which does guarantee those rights, those freedoms and those liberties that I think we are so anxious to maintain and develop. Sadly I think, parliament itself is lacking in that regard too. That has come about, unfortunately, because of the growth of the powers of the Executive, and that executive power being taken from the Parliament. The Executive has too great an influence on the parliamentary processes, so unfortunately parliament is not that keeper of the rights and liberties of the community that it might otherwise be. Given the problem of the common law and given, too, the fact that the media, which certainly sees itself in large measure as also a protector of the rights and liberties of the people of this nation, also have great defects-I will not go into that at the moment-there is raised a very serious question of whether or not a Bill of Rights should be brought in to give protection to those liberties.

The problems that that involves have been raised already, and they include questions involving the judiciary. I have the highest respect for the judges of this country and for the profession that practises in the courts. Nevertheless, the fact does remain that judges are not elected by the people and they do tend at times, perhaps with the passing of time, not to appreciate as much as they might the questions of liberty and freedoms that do arise.

In those circumstances ought there be a Bill of Rights? That is the question that we have to face from now on. It is a question which, as I say, is a fundamental question for the parliamentary process to look at. The document produced certainly forms a proper and detailed analysis of the sorts of concepts that should be brought forward in that debate. I hope that the concepts brought forward in this document are the ones debated. Unfortunately, certain propositions are being put forward which seem to me to be quite wrong and which lead to an emotional discussion of the issues that are raised. I have nothing against emotional arguments so long as in the end they produce something that is correct. It will be unfortunate if the whole debate about a Bill of Rights becomes full of acrimony rather than full of light and logic. I simply recommend not only to honourable senators but also to people in the community who are interested in this question that they read this excellent report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report being debated tonight is the exposure report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the question of a Bill of Rights for Australia. The report opens up the issue of human rights in Australia and whether Australia really needs a Bill of Rights at all. Some of the options that the Committee puts down are hard for me to accept. I realise that they are only options, but I have some difficulty with them. From the founding of the Commonwealth in 1901 to the present day we have lived in the freest society in the world. We have been the envy of every nation in the world because of our freedoms. We have done this without having a Bill of Rights and without listing our rights. Under our system of law our rights are open ended. They are contained only by legal restraints. Conversely, under a Bill of Rights, our rights will be limited. In a Westminster style of democracy such as Australia has, our rights are acquired at birth. The problem with listing our rights is that they become open to manipulation through the interpretation of words.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill of Rights, if it gets the assent of Parliament, will depend on an international covenant to dictate the rights of every Australian. We will be introducing an international covenant as an Australian law. We have only to look at the signatories to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights that have Bills of Rights to see what little a Bill of Rights does to protect human rights. Does the Bill of Rights in the Soviet Union ensure human rights for the Baltic people? What do the Estonians, the Lithuanians and the Latvians think of the human rights afforded by the Russian Bill? Russia has what is the equivalent of a human rights Bill. I wonder what the Afghans think of the Russian human rights Bill. I wonder whether they find any comfort in it. I am sure that they do not. My point is that if Australia wishes human rights to be entrenched in the workings of the Australian people, no legislation will help it.

A major concern with the proposed Bill of Rights is that it is an attack on State rights. Senator Bolkus tonight openly attacked State rights. State rights are enshrined in our Constitution. They are the basis of this nation's federalism policy. Federalism is what every member of this Senate is here to protect. All senators are here to protect the rights of their States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—That is what we are here for. That is provided under the Constitution. Perhaps Senator Walsh wants to rip up the Constitution. It is to stop the encroachment of the Commonwealth over State governments, whether they be Liberal, Labor or National Party.
—Who wrote that for you?

—I wrote it myself. The Bill proposes the very opposite of what the Constitution meant for the role of the States. This Bill, if it is passed by this Parliament in its present form, will control State laws, State Cabinet decisions and even local council decisions. The Human Rights Commission, under the proposed Bill of Rights, is given increased powers. It will be a quasi-political body. It is not elected, it is not independent like the judicial system; it is given wide powers of inquiry into State laws and local government Acts. It has the power to demand attendance of people and the disclosure of documents, even if they are self-incriminating. It does not provide protection by means of the rules of evidence and it does not allow legal representation. If this is not an infringement of human rights, I do not know what is. Where are the human rights when an articulate person is able to put his or her case clearly and a battler with little education cannot do so and is at a distinct disadvantage? Where are the human rights in that?

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Committee gives options on how a Bill of Rights should work. I note that the report refers to States being able to opt out of the Bill of Rights. Every State government concerned with State rights should use this opportunity. This will probably saddle Canberra with a Bill of Rights-it will be the only government with one because all the States will opt out. The States must show that they have sovereign powers and are not subservient to Canberra. Every State in Australia will feel justified in opting out because of the wrongful encroachment by the Commonwealth into State government responsibilities. For 84 years States have been allowed to exercise control over State matters because of their constitutional rights. Now this Government is using the loophole of the external affairs section of the Constitution to override the elected State governments. If this Government wants a Bill of Rights, I suggest that it put the question to the people in the form of a referendum because this Constitution does not belong to the Australian Labor Party, it belongs to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to participate in the debate this evening but four points were made by Senator Boswell in his contribution to which I wish to reply because they either misstate the facts or they misrepresent the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I do not think that his remarks should be allowed to pass without comment. The four points that he made were as follows: First, he said that the proposed Bill of Rights-whatever he means by that-would override State laws. The Committee did not discuss and has not reported upon the Bill which is in the House of Representatives. As a simple matter of fact the Bill which is in the House of Representatives specifically excludes the Bill of Rights having reference to State laws. That is the first misstatement of fact. He misstates the fact as far as the Bill that is in the House of Representatives is concerned and he misrepresents the position of the Committee which did not discuss and does not report upon the Bill which is in the House of Representatives and simply canvasses arguments about the validity of the Bill of Rights which might or might not impinge upon State laws.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, he asks what is the good of having some adherence to an international covenant when rogues and villains are adherents to the same covenant. The Committee specifically addresses this matter. In paragraph 3.56 we draw attention to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in 1979 on `Human Rights in the Soviet Union'. This deals specifically with the fact that the Soviet Union being a signatory to some covenant means in itself absolutely nothing about the protection of human rights in that country. Senator Boswell's argument fails to acknowledge the criticism which the Committee itself directs to those people whose adherence to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is purely a token gesture to the international community and is not something meaningful.

The third point that Senator Boswell makes touches upon the opting out provisions. He advises and proclaims that all the States of the Commonwealth should take the opportunity to opt out because not to opt out is to admit to an extension of Federal power which is undesirable in a federation. The provinces of Canada are no less jealous of their status as members of the Canadian Federation and those provinces were provided under the Canadian charter of rights with a means by which they could opt out eventually of the Canadian bill of rights proposals. Only one province in Canada decided to opt out, and that was Quebec. It opted out for reasons which are obvious, which are historical and which do not need elaboration this evening. I note that Senator Bolkus in his remarks referred on three occasions to Queensland as `that country' as distinct from `that State'. Perhaps there is some lesson in that freudian slip on his part, as indeed there may be some lesson in the Canadian situation in which Quebec really feels that it has so little in common with the rest of Canada or so much to fear from the rest of Canada that it must opt out of the system. Nevertheless, let it be said that there are provisions in the Canadian system which prevent Canada from derogating from the electoral rights which are provided or the guarantees on the linguistic integrity of the Canadian federation which need to be borne in mind.

The fourth point Senator Boswell made was in regard to the use of the external affairs power. May I say that the Committee in its report deals at length with heads of power questions. It acknowledges fairly and squarely that the use of the external affairs power is a partisan, political, sensitive issue and it seeks to draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that that is the case and to put squarely to the Senate that to embark upon that road would involve a degree of political animosity within the federation which is undesirable. It is for that reason that the Committee's preferred model is not to use the external affairs powers; rather, to enact some form of domestic legislation and to establish, without going down the whole of the sorry track--

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you going to do that?

—Senator Boswell asks how are we going to do that. May I say with the greatest of respect to Senator Boswell that those of us who have spent several months on this inquiry, who have read the 168 submissions, who have sat for hours, who have listened to witnesses, who have gone through innumerable drafts, are entitled to respond to Senator Boswell by saying: `Senator, read the report'. It is not for me to answer the question tonight when a document which answers the questions has been presented to the Senate. I do not intend to go through the length of that argument when the honourable senator has been presented with the arguments cogently put, I hope, and argued in such a way that those of us-and let me make my own position clear-who do not believe in the use of a Bill of Rights are nevertheless able to come to the Senate with a unanimous report which is an exposure report, bringing the issues before the Senate; attempting to present them, to present the arguments, and to bring about a situation in which the Committee report does not make recommendations on the threshold question of whether we should have a Bill. That is left as an open question because that was not the purpose of the report. The purpose of the report was to answer, for those who are prepared to read it, the questions which Senator Boswell raised in tonight's debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think therefore that one needs to see this report for what it is. It is an attempt to put the issues squarely on the table. It is an attempt to say to honourable senators that this is a most difficult and complex question. The way in which one goes about the fundamental protection of human rights is an open question. My own preference happens to be for specific legislation. I believe there ought to be specific legislation on questions such as the protection of privacy. I happen to believe that as matters are identified as being under threat or under challenge-to find from the courts, for instance, something of which I was not aware until we got into this debate, that there is absolutely no common law protection for the free exercise of religious freedom in Australia-we have to try to expose what the weaknesses of the common law are and at the same time to acknowledge the very real strengths of the common law, which have been built on a tradition dating back beyond Magna Carta. There are the questions of the relationship between parliament and the Crown and parliament and the Executive. There are the questions of whether parliament is properly to be regarded as an absolute sovereign in terms of the definition of rights, the relationship between parliament and the judiciary and between elected and non-elected officials in the protection of human rights. All this exposure report attempts to do is to leave those questions open to the judgment of honourable senators and to people in the wider community who are interested in this debate.

As Senator Cooney said in his remarks, the debate on this matter will be lengthy. I hope it will be a debate which will stretch beyond simply the involvement of honourable senators within this chamber. If, after all, we are talking about the rights of ordinary Australian citizens, they cannot be represented simply by the 168 people who put submissions to us. There will be wider views in the community to be considered when specific legislation comes before us. This report seeks simply to present issues, arguments and, above all, facts. To that extent I believe that the Committee has discharged the responsibilities which the Senate imposed upon it. It has confined itself properly to the terms of reference. It has not strayed beyond those. It has not considered what it was prevented from considering by Senator Durack's amendment-namely, any specific legislative proposals.

I hope, therefore, that when the debate comes on, in whatever fashion and on whatever piece of legislation it comes on, this report will have served a useful purpose in presenting facts and arguments to honourable senators. If honourable senators are going to criticise either the legislation of the Committee report I hope that they will do their colleagues the elementary courtesy of reading it first.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT BILL 1985INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was speaking on the Interstate Road Transport Bill. At that stage I was suggesting how ill-advised the Government was to press ahead with this legislation. I was indicating that I believe that there are very many reasons why the Government should not do so now. First of all, as I have said before, there is the Inter-State Commission inquiry into the cost recovery of road and rail services. This inquiry will not be completed until something like 30 April. As part of the package of Federal-State uniform legislation we have to consider the various State legislation. Having listened to the various speakers in this debate today, I would say that this legislation is hardly yet the light at the end of the tunnel. It will be many months, perhaps a year, before the States are ready. The vagueness of the legislation means that many Federal regulations will have to be drafted to bring some strength and basis to it.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said that this is a Federal-State package, but here we see the Federal Government bringing in its legislation at least six months, probably 12 months, prior to the States' legislation, and one wonders the reason for this. Is it to be regarded as guidelines for the States, or merely as an indication to the States that they have to fall into line? It seems to me that if this legislation adds substantially to the cost of transportation it will mean a passing on of increased costs to the consumers of goods transported by road, and perhaps also by rail. There is an interesting side to this. Senator Archer quoted a Government speaker as suggesting that for the State governments there would be improvements in rail cost recovery to match any improvement in cost recovery in the road freight section, and that this would apply also to the Australian National Railways Commission. It appears as a rather ominous warning that we shall see increases not only in road freight but in rail charges too.

The people of the Northern Territory in outback remote areas-and this of course applies to Western Australia, South Australia, New South Wales and Queensland-are already suffering under the burden of high prices for the necessities of life. We have seen the cost of fuel and other necessities increasing dramatically in this last year. A submission by the Department of Transport and Works in the Northern Territory to the inquiry that is taking place at the moment points out that an increase of 5c per litre of fuel from 50c to 55c means an extra freight cost of $2 per tonne from Brisbane to Darwin.

Another item of considerable interest is that the Australian Bureau of Statistics released a report in September showing that the cost of goods and services in Darwin rose more in the three months up to September last than in any State capital city. The consumer price index, which measures the inflation rate, showed that Darwin's costs rose by 3.5 per cent in the three months to September. That was Darwin, but there are many other places in the outback and remote areas which are also suffering these extreme costs. Frankly, I do not think it right that these people who are prepared to live in remote areas-admittedly they have made the choice-should have such costs passed on to them, as it appears will happen under the present legislation.

As I have said, I support the approach of my coalition colleagues, which is to defer consideration of this legislation until such time as the Inter-State Commission reports to the Minister and we have some indication from him as to what tax will be imposed. This will give everyone time to look at the legislation properly and, given the Government's professed commitment to consultation and consensus, I am sure it would agree that the industry deserves at least that courtesy. I refer not only to the industry, particularly to independent truck owners who apparently are not being heard, but also to the States and the Northern Territory.

In closing I point out that, while I wish to see consideration of the legislation deferred, as I have indicated before, I am not opposed to those aspects of the legislation which deal with the need to improve safety standards and a more uniform approach to safety in the road transport industry. I know that those in the industry welcome measures designed to ensure their safety and the safety of other road users. Once again I make the point that, even though this legislation might be passed now by the Government, it will not be enacted for some six to 12 months, so it will have no effect on road safety measures until that time. We will have to rely on those safety measures at present enshrined in State legislation. In closing his speech, Senator Archer, the shadow Minister for the coalition in regard to this legislation, moved the following amendment on behalf of the Opposition:

Leave out all words after `That', insert `these Bills be withdrawn and redrafted to remove the current excessive reliance on regulation, for presentation in redrafted form at the commencement of the 1986 Autumn sittings'.
I think this is a very real and necessary request and I support Senator Archer wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Interstate Road Transport Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill. I want to raise a few matters in connection with this legislation. Every year I drive tens of thousands of kilometres around Victoria, mainly on country roads but a great deal on major highways and, in particular, the Hume Highway. Some aspects of that driving have caused me concern over the years. The first thing is the very extensive use of backroads by very large motor vehicles, even the 26-wheeler vehicles. Those back roads are being maintained by shires around the State of Victoria. The damage which is done to those roads by such enormous vehicles causes the shire engineers much concern. A lot of damage is done by motorists, such as myself, just driving ordinary motor cars around those back roads trying to seek some quicker way to our destinations.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised that matter only to draw the Government's attention to the fact that our State shires are not receiving adequate funds to maintain the road services that they are providing. Mr Deputy President, you will recall that, when we were in government, you had a considerable amount to say about road funding. A shire engineer put it succinctly to me by saying: `Senator, you are providing funds for us as if the roads will last 80 years when the truth of the matter is that they will last only 20 years'. All around Australia shire engineers are struggling to maintain our roads in some sort of condition. I congratulate them on their efforts. I say to the Federal and State governments that these are matters of infrastructure and basic matters of national importance that governments ought to be looking at. Both Federal and State governments ought to be looking at ways of providing adequate funds of the proper maintenance of all our roads.

I turn now to deal with the truckies, many of whom would now be out on the Hume Highway between Melbourne and Sydney. Believe me, during the course of the night there is an enormous volume of traffic on that road. I might say to motorists who are thinking of driving along that road that the best time to do so is during the day when the truckies are not on the road. I want to thank most of those truckies for the courtesy which they offer car drivers. Most of them drive sensibly. They indicate with their blinkers when it is safe or unsafe to pass them. However, there are many truckies on the roads who drive, especially at night, at enormous, frightening speeds. They drive along at 120 kilometres an hour. I have been passed by a 26-wheeled truck carrying probably 40 tonnes and, believe me, it is a frightening experience.

I can recall one wet evening at around 10.30 when I was driving near Wangaratta on the Hume Highway. I was in a smallish car. It was pouring with rain and there was mud and slush on the roads. I was driving at 110 kilometres an hour. I was passed by a convoy of eight 26-wheeled trucks. Clearly, the trucks were in convoy and were travelling at a speed in excess of 120 kilometres an hour. The distance between each would not have been more than a truck's length. I presume that by way of their radios they were signalling to each other or speaking to each other about whether they could overtake or not at a certain point, but I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that it was so frightening that I stopped at the next motel and decided that I would not continue my journey.

It is that sort of thing which, unfortunately demonstrates the need for the sort of legislation which is before the Senate tonight. I do not know how such behaviour is to be controlled, except by the truck drivers themselves. If they are being pushed by their contractors, their employers and so on, clearly they have to take some action which will enable them to drive at more modest speeds. I acknowledge that they are excellent drivers. I acknowledge that, considering the volume of traffic and the speed at which these vehicles travel on the highways, the number of accidents is fairly small. Nevertheless, the few accidents that occur are terrible accidents.

Members of the Senate would know that I have always been a good supporter of the police forces. I stick up for the police as much as I can, but I must say that my experience has been that the traffic police, especially on the roads of New South Wales, are being used as tax gatherers. I do not say that it is necessarily their fault. I believe that it started with the Wran Government, which became so desperately short of money a few years back that it sold off the State. When it finished selling off the State it took every other opportunity to find any money that was hidden anywhere and then took other steps to recover funds from whichever source it could recover them. Clearly, it saw that motorists could be raped not only by way of registration fees, licence fees, petrol fees and all the other fees that are paid but also by way of policemen fining them for speeding offences on the spot.

It has been my experience that in New South Wales especially-I know it occurs in some places in Victoria but it is certainly not as bad there as it is in New South Wales-traffic officers, in order to raise the revenue which clearly they have to raise, hide on long straight stretches of the roadway and with their radar guns pick off anyone who is passing. That is certainly a way of raising revenue. I do not believe that the Government has given them some written direction that they have to raise revenue in this way. In some way or other the senior officers must reward the constables by telling them that they have been very good this week; they have raised x thousands of dollars whereas someone else has not raised much and he had better get out and do his job. Of course it is possible to raise revenue by hiding on a long straight stretch of road and using the radar gun, or by hiding around a corner immediately following a long straight stretch of road using a radar gun, to pick up motorists who are exceeding 100 kilometres an hour, especially on a two-lane freeway. To be fined for exceeding 100 kilometres an hour in a modern motor vehicle on a two-lane divided freeway seems to be the height of nonsense. That is not a way of keeping our roads safe. The police know how to keep the roads safe. They need to patrol openly the dangerous sections. They need to drive slowly and carefully around the dangerous sections with their blue lights flashing and the motorists will all slow down. That would provide the police with less revenue and the people of Australia with fewer accidents.

I have referred to truckies who drive at speeds in excess of 120 kilometres an hour in a 26-wheeler which weighs many tonnes. It is appal- ling to think about it. However, I have never managed to see such a truck stopped by a policeman who writes out a ticket for a speeding fine. I presume that it must happen but truck drivers are so well co-ordinated with their citizen band radios and they tick tack to one another so much that the location of the police is clearly identified and the truckies slow down as they pass a police trap. The result is that the truckies are able to maintain extraordinary high speeds on open highways. It is a matter of major concern. Clearly, something has to be done in order to bring about some safety on our roads.

Having said that, I turn to the legislation which has been introduced by this Government. Although I understand what might be behind it, I have to say that it is not properly thought out. As the Opposition will disclose at the Committee stage of the Bill, the legislation enables the Government to introduce regulation after regulation in more than 50 clauses which provide facilities to enable self-incrimination by way of those regulations. The Bill is far too open to abuse through those regulatory powers conferred on the Minister and the Government has not allowed the States to develop their own programs and legislation. We understand that three States have indicated that they will not support the legislation. In those circumstances and given the fact that this Bill will not commence operation until 1 July 1986, I put it to the Senate that the course proposed by the Opposition, that is, that the Bill be deferred pending consultations with the States and the trucking organisations, is the right and proper course to adopt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Of course, I have not heard a great deal of the debate. However, what I have heard has not been particularly relevant in my view to the substance of the legislation-marginally relevant anyway. I am advised that, strickly speaking, four amendments will be moved at the Committee stage either by Senator Vigor or someone else from the Australian Democrats. The Government will accept those amendments. The Opposition has moved a second reading amendment to have the Bills withdrawn. The Government, of course, will not agree to that amendment. It is necessary that some order be brought to the chaos which has existed in the industry for too long. It is the Government's wish that the Bills be passed as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Archer's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Referral To Standing Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 196A, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985 be referred to the Standing Committee on National Resources for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in February 1986.

The Opposition members of the Committee are confident that this is reasonable for the Committee. These Bills are a perfect example of the sort of Bill that should be referred to a Senate committee for public examination. There is no urgency about the Bills. Even the so-called fast track provision of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) cannot be proclaimed before 1 July next year. There have been claims of insufficient consultation with large sections of the industry. There are problems with the regulations, which it is claimed are too general and too broad. The agreements with the States are not yet finalised. The Inter-State Commission is in the process of producing a report on cost recovery for interstate road and rail services.

I do not want to repeat all the arguments that were used in the second reading debate, but I merely reiterate that the weight of them is such that it would be irresponsible of this Senate to pass the Bills without having the implications thoroughly and publicly investigated by a Senate committee, and I have moved accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the referral of the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. The Democrats have received a number of submissions from organisations representing truckies. I have here a telegram from the Federal Conference of the Federated Long Distance Transport Association of Australia, held in Victoria on 6 October 1985. The telegram reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At the Association's Federal Conference held in Victoria on 6th October 1985 the Executive and members fully endorsed the proposed Inter-State Road Transport Bill 1985. We believe the expedition of this Bill to be paramount to the well-being of operators within the road transport industry. Any delay to the passage of this Bill will only lead to a situation of confusion and unrest within the industry. We seek your support in this matter.
W. F. Brennan Secretary Federated Long Distance Transport Association of Australia.
We have also received a number of submissions from Queensland, New South Wales, Western Australia and Victoria concerning the expedition of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does South Australia say?

—I attended in South Australia a meeting of some 200 people who had been totally misinformed by Barry Lewis about matters associated with the Bill. He had misinterpreted the Bill. In fact, a dodger was distributed in South Australia and I seek leave to incorporate this dodger in Hansard as an example of the type of information being put out on the Bill in my State.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dodger was distributed by the Professional Transport Drivers Association of South Australia and authorised by Barry Lewis. It makes the accusation that the Bill introduces a road tax. It is headed, in large letters, `Road Tax', and states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has introduced legislation to impose a road transport tax. (It could be approximately 5 cents per kilometre!) The Federal Government intends to license your business.
The Federal Government will force you to fit a ``charge monitoring device'' on your truck and trailer to record the kilometres travelled.
If this ``monitoring device'' falls off your truck or trailer on rough roads and you keep operating you have committed an offence.
If you break the law the Federal Government has the power to expel you from the transport industry for life.
Please contact the Democrat and Liberal Senators URGENTLY.

The ``Interstate Road Transport Bill'' must be adjourned until the Interstate Commission reports to the Minister in April, 1986 so that further consideration and consultation with the industry is achieved.

Every paragraph of the dodger, apart from the very useful one asking the truckies to contact Democrat and Liberal senators, which in fact they have done, is filled with misunderstandings concerning the Bill. We have talked to those truckies and they have formed a seven-member committee, which met on Monday night. A spokesman for that committee talked with me and gave me a set of amendments that would be acceptable to the committee. I have taken those amendments to the Government and the Government has accepted them. I have since talked to Mr Barry Lewis, who wrote the dodger, and he has told me that he is happy with the proposals that have been put forward. I believe that this is a success for consensus within the industry and a success for the Democrats, who have been able to act as honest brokers in this business and to bring together all of the associations instead of simply sitting back, as the Opposition has done in this case, and saying: `Delay, delay, delay'.

The motion before us to refer the matter to a committee is yet another delaying tactic. I am disgusted with the proposal to delay. I was quite happy to look at delaying the Bill if all the perceived problems had not been resolved but in my mind and in the minds of my fellow Democrats all of the worries put forward by the independent truckies and the people from each of the State organisations who contacted us will be satisfied by the amendments that we will be moving in the Committee stage and that the Government says it accepts.

We need this legislation. I heard Senator Lewis talking about being scared on the highway. That has happened to me as well. We need the safety regulations and we need them quickly. We need a bat to make the State governments introduce their complementary legislation. We need a way of introducing order into an industry. Yet members of the Opposition are sitting back howling about the subject and trying to delay the legislation. People are being killed on the roads. That is what the issue is. We want to get this legislation through. I hope that we will manage to do so tonight and that nobody will hold it up. I am quite happy that we have effectively managed to satisfy all the many organisations and people who have rung my office-10 to 20 a day. I have taken notes and we have ticked off the things that they have asked us. I am happy about it. The Democrats will not support the referral to a committee because we believe that the referral is just another delaying tactic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not expected the Australian Democrats to support the common sense that we are trying to get into this debate. I think it is necessary to look at a few of the facts in relation to the interstate road transport legislation. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in his second reading speech on 8 October, in one paragraph said:

SPEECH.PARA: The report and the subsequent fast-track package have received broad industry and general community support as these groups have recognised that the recommendations must be implemented as a package.
A bit later on he said:
I cannot emphasise too strongly the importance of the co-operation that has been shown by the States and Territory governments, the industry, unions and users.

Those two statements are patently incorrect. Those of us who looked at the legislation in the early stages fairly naturally believed that the Minister had told us what the position was. What we find, of course, is that the States have not agreed and that an extraordinarily large proportion of the users have not agreed. Just to show the Senate that what I have said is correct, I will read portions of submissions made by some of the State Ministers. One of them says:

As the sole rationale for States participation in the scheme is to receive some funds out of it, all States should have an input in determining the distribution formula . . . before he nominates the roads on which the funds are to be spent.
A bit later on it says:

In addition to the above the Government is concerned about the possible use of section 34 of the Bill . . . specific conflicts between State authorities and then only with the agreement of the States through ATAC or one of its sub-committees is the way that it should work.
Another Minister said:

. . . the Federal Minister already has sole responsibility for the distribution of national road funds . . . taking these factors into account, I have agreed that the draft legislation should, if possible, be amended to incorporate the distribution principles . . .
This is a long way from being the sort of agreement that the Minister has talked about, or that Senator Vigor is of the opinion is correct. Clearly and patently it is not. Another Minister said:
Administratively, the Bill is cumbersome and would involve considerable additional workload.
Later he went on:

To help ensure that the new fee is constitutional, the Commonwealth has separately requested the Interstate Commission to investigate and recommend an appropriate level for the cost recovery-based fee . . . The problems are seen to be that the Commonwealth is seeking greater powers than it needs to, to achieve these objectives which would then compromise State/Territory powers and regulatory efforts. Because the detail had not been thought through, the legislation is too open-ended . . . the impression is the Commonwealth Minister is committed to proceeding with both the operator and registration provisions and through lack of advice, to retain provision for separate Federal safety standards and for offences where State Territory offences already exist.

A major problem appears to be that the Commonwealth officers involved have not appreciated the practical issues nor the scope for open-ended legislation to be abused over time. Their Minister has not been advised as to how to legislate to achieve the original purpose and avoid creating unnecessary concerns for the States Territories.

That is the sort of thing that has come through from the States already. This is the way that they see it. They have had to work on the presumption of the contents of the Bill and their work is based on very limited opportunities to examine the detailed implications. The operator licensing provisions are seen to be premature and the detail of how they are to operate has not been adequately thought out. It presumes too much on parliament. The remaining differences reflect mainly variations in regional considerations or delays by some administrations in implementation. Potential problems appear not to have been understood by Commonwealth officials. A much simpler, more effective approach would be for the safety requirements, of the State or Territory in which the vehicle is, to be met as at present and a further effort made to remove the few remaining differences between the State and Territory requirements. This is what the Minister told us had all been agreed. Agreed, my foot! We are a long way from getting this to the stage where we can accept it as legislation.

I have had a quick run through the main Bill and looking at the areas which require regulations, I found 50 separate clauses that I believe will have to be covered by regulations. To have what will amount to 70 or 80 regulations-because a lot of those clauses will require more than one regulation-in a Bill as small as this is asking too much of the industry, the State governments and this Parliament. If the Democrats want to fall for this business of giving an open cheque to the Labor Party whenever it asks for it, that is up to them. But it will not happen as far as the Opposition is concerned. It is our responsibility to see that this legislation is in a fit and proper condition when it comes before the House. If we are to get on with this legislation, let us look at these matters clause by clause and let us have some answers from the Government as to what this is all about. There are so many open-ended issues and so many questions not answered. Issues were raised in the second reading speech that are nothing to do with the Bill in any way, shape or form.

There is this question of the Inter-state Commission. Why is the Inter-state Commission making an inquiry if we are not even going to wait for the outcome? What is the point of the Government giving undertakings and kidding Senator Vigor about a $1,400 figure that it is prepared to put in the legislation when a couple of lines further down the page it says that it will take advice from the Inter-state Commission? I feel sorry for Senator Vigor. He has been sucked into believing this sort of rubbish. He has been hoodwinked and hoaxed in every possible way. I think it is time this House took the matter really in hand and made sure that it got the answers. I would be surprised if, on the information that we have before us, we would be able to line up all the road transport operators in Australia and put them through this rigmarole. I am very disappointed that the Government has not seen fit to take the advice it has been getting from the industry, from the State governments and from the Opposition. So be it; it is on the Government's head. But the Bill will certainly not go through without our complaining and I would certainly hope that the Democrats even yet will come to listen to the arguments that will take place in the Committee stage and get some sense from them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the suggestion which has been made in this debate that the interstate road transport legislation ought to be referred to a Senate committee on the ground that we need to have regard to the small transport operators in Australia. Senator Vigor made the comment that all of the transport interests have been satisfied. I believe that that is not right. He made some comment concerning Mr Barry Lewis, who represents a considerable number of people who are interested in this legislation.
—He certainly does not represent the Tasmanians.

—Senator Walters mentions the Tasmanian transport interests. I mentioned in my speech earlier today that its interests happen to be quite important, because to my knowledge all of the States except New South Wales are very concerned about the impact of this legislation on transport operators in the States. The Northern Territory has demonstrated its reservations. Fifty clauses of the Interstate Road Transport Bill are the subject of regulation. The Labor Government says that it is interested in deregulation. Certainly the Opposition is interested in deregulation. Yet 50 clauses of the Bill are subjected to ministerial decision with respect to what happens in the industry. I think that that is bad, particularly for Tasmania. I mentioned that fact earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vigor dares, as a new senator, who has no idea of the implications of the Bill, to say that all interests have been consulted. He dares to make some comment about Barry Lewis, the representative of the Professional Transport Drivers Association which represents the interests of small business. The Democrats are parading before Australians as representatives of small business. They are desperately trying to survive in this place. Yet Senator Vigor says that everybody has been consulted. That is wrong, and that is an incredible indictment of the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the people who have contacted us have been satisified.

—The honourable senator is wrong, and he is demonstrably wrong. It highlights the insincerity and ignorance of the Australian Democrats in this Parliament. The sooner they are eliminated from the Senate, the better it will be. The Opposition recognises the need to improve the safety aspects of the industry, the need to introduce graduated licences and the need for access to consumer protection arrangements, all of which will be done by the States. Senator Vigor does not recognise that because he has not studied the proposition-
—You did not read my speech.

—I do not read the honourable senator's speeches. I listen to the nonsense that he talks in this place. The Opposition supports the introduction of registration fees for interstate operators, to bring them in line with the appropriate fees for intrastate operators. However, there are a number of measures in the Bill that we are particularly disturbed about. I do not think the Democrats have given any thought to this aspect. The Press release of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) of 26 October this year gives us cause to be very concerned. In the first paragraph of his Press release he states that owners and operators of interstate trucks will not have to pay any more than a $1,400 registration fee for a typical 38- tonne semi-trailer under the new interstate road transport legislation. In the seventh paragraph-I will quote it for the benefit of my colleague Senator Vigor-the Minister assures the industry:

SPEECH.PARA: No change would be made to the fee until the Interstate Commission had presented its report on road and rail cost recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has four months.
—The honourable senator has four months to make up his mind about that.
—He will need it, too.
—Exactly. My colleague from Western Australia says--
—We think faster than you.
—Do I need to comment on that?
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair.

—Mr President, the Queensland Government, the Western Australian Government, the Tasmanian Government, the Northern Territory Government and the representatives at the Australian Transport Advisory Council conference have all expressed grave concern about this Bill. I think the satisfactory arrangement would be to refer it to a committee of the Senate so that an appropriate in-depth examination could be made of its implications for the transport operators of Australia. If we pass this legislation it will impose greater costs on the industry. It will mean that many small operators will go to the wall. There will be unemployment. The Hawke Labor Government purports to represent small enterprise in Australia. This legislation simply props up big operations and big unions and acts against the interests of the small operators. Therefore, I believe that the Opposition's approach to this legislation is appropriate-the approach that supports small enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats purport to represent small groups. They should look at what the word `democrat' means. It means democracy, something that is supposed to be fair to all. But the Democrats have chosen to support big unions and big enterprise and to ignore the democratic rights of the small people who are affected by this measure. I think that stands as an indictment of the Australian Democrats. In this place they have a history of purporting to represent minority groups. They talk in this place about environmental matters in Tasmania. They talk about animal liberation-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator is getting away from the terms of the motion before the Chair.
—Thank you for your guidance, Mr President. I am just illustrating the lengths to which the Australian Democrats will go in this Parliament to--
—Justice.
—Justice?
—That is right, justice.
—We have a renegade American here--
—Order! I suggest that Senator Jessop come back to the terms of the motion before the Chair.

—I suggest that the Democrats, including the former American citizen who is now an Australian citizen and who purports to represent all the minority groups in Australia, ought to direct their attention to the small business people operating in the transport industry. I do not regard the honourable senator as an Australian. I think he is a renegade American who has come into the chamber to interrupt-
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is a personal denigration and I do not think it has any place in this chamber.

—Order! The honourable senator has taken objection to the words used by Senator Jessop. I therefore ask Senator Jessop, under standing order 418, to withdraw any imputation against the honourable senator.
—Well, I will say he is a renegade Australian.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to withdraw.

—I withdraw. I want to make the point that the Democrats in this Parliament represent a minority view, and on this occasion they are disregarding the small operators in the road transport area. Therefore, I am surprised particularly with Senator Vigor, for whom I have a great regard. I serve on a committee with him and we work together, but I am surprised that he has disregarded the small operators in the context of this Bill. He has disregarded the importance of referring this important question to a Senate committee for close examination. I believe that in rejecting that proposition he is supporting big business and big unions in Australia. I believe that deserves the condemnation of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far be it from me to defend the Australian Democrats-they are big enough and old enough to look after themselves on this occasion and indeed on all others-but I am moved to rise by Senator Jessop's reference in the course of his rather squalid little filibuster here tonight, which he will no doubt regret when he wakes in the morning with a clearer head than he manifestly has at the moment--
—On a point of order, Mr President: I object to that allegation. It is uncalled for. I was speaking from a position of concern about the particular Bill. It is not unusual for the Minister--
—Order! Senator Jessop has taken his point of order. Clearly there was an imputation under standing order 418 on the part of the Minister. I ask him to withdraw his remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.
—You are a disgrace-an absolute disgrace.

—I will come to Tasmania in a moment. I am moved to rise, as I have said, by Senator Jessop's reference in the course of his speech to insincerity and ignorance. There is indeed no better exponent of those particular qualities than Senator Jessop in this place. He has displayed them in good measure in his contribution here tonight, not least in his assertion that the States in general, and I think he said Tasmania in particular-something Senator Archer also said in his contribution-had not accepted the principles embodied in this particular package.
—I did not.

—That was the inference, as I understand it, in what Senator Archer said. To the extent that there was an inference in what Senator Archer said, but much more explicitly in what Senator Jessop said, I think it is appropriate to put on the record an extract of a speech made by Tasmanian Premier Gray to the Australian Road Transport Federation convention just a few days ago, on 20 October this year. What he said in relation to the report in question on which this legislation is based was this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Report has also been welcomed by my Government. We have announced our support in principle for the package of recommendations developed by the Inquiry. Already a fast-track package incorporating a set of the Inquiry's recommendations selected for early implementation has been adopted by the Australian Transport Advisory Council.

I interpolate there that that is the body of Ministers from all States, and all States through their Ministers accepted at that ATAC meeting the elements of the legislation that have been before us tonight. Premier Gray went on:
My Government has expressed its support for the fast-track package and is currently working on means of implementing those recommendations requiring State Government action.

It is appropriate that those matters be put on the public record because there has been a series of, as I understand it, complete misstatements about the effect so far as the States are concerned of this particular legislative package and their response to it. I believe that in that speech made by Robin Gray there purporting to speak on behalf of all State Premiers, we have the lie to so many assertions made in the course of this debate tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is deliberately misleading the chamber. He made a comment about the acceptance of the report. There is no question about the acceptance or otherwise of the report. We are talking about the legislation in this place. While he chooses to quote what the Premier of Tasmania--
—Order! The honourable senator is now debating the issue. To date he has made no point of order. I ask him to come to his point of order.

—My point of order is that the Minister has deliberately misled the Senate on the basis that he is quoting what somebody said about the report when what we have been talking about is the legislation. They are two entirely different things and the Minister knows it.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I will let the quality of that contribution and that particular distinction speak for itself. I simply make the point that there is no case for referring this legislation to the Committee. The motion that has been moved by Senator Hamer should be rejected out of hand accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some regret that I rise to speak in support of this motion.
